{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3635896,"name":"Arjun Bhatia","username":"ABhatia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/90db22/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-26T02:48:04.121Z","cooked":"

We used two sets of the Adafruit beam break sensor during competition this year for coral indexing, and they worked great indoors!

However, as we are starting outreach events with robot demos outdoors, we are having issues where the they are false-unbroken due to interference from the sun. Coral will pass through the beam and not stop, since the sensor is not detecting ‘beam broken’.

Any recommendations on how to overcome this? Software changes? 3D printed shroud? Alternative sensors? (we have been looking into capacitive).

IR is one of many things the sun tosses at us. There’s a couple of options you have.

My first option would be a shroud, not necessarily 3D printed. Some of the older FLL students will remember that a box lined with tinfoil was generally a wise thing to bring to competition so you could program your robot without having to worry about accidentally programming someone else’s robot with the IR lines.

So what you’re going to be looking at for the shroud is IR-blocking. Use a TV remote (older) to check, along with a camera. If you can get a signal from the remote through something, it doesn’t block IR, try again. (It’ll show up as a bright light if it shows up.)

Besides that, I’d probably try ultrasonic sensors.
